question: should the government fight recessions with spending hikes rather than tax cuts?

clueweb22-en0007-34-08862.point_content: Spending hikes are a perfect solution in battling recessions as they provide a monetary boost to attain higher levels of economic activity and overall economic welfare.
spans: Spending hikes, therefore, would be a perfect solution in battling recessions.

clueweb22-en0007-34-08862.point_content: According to Keynes, fiscal stimulus through government spending is necessary to escape economic slowdown during recessions.
spans: According to Keynes, fiscal stimulus and freedom from a state of economic slowdown in such a situation can only be achieved by an “injection” of government spending into the economy.

clueweb22-en0007-34-08862.point_content: In a recession, a rise in taxes will not affect overall market spending because consumers have already stopped spending, allowing government borrowing to act as expansionary fiscal policy.
spans: Will real GDP rise if taxations and government spending are increased by the same amount? Yes. In a recession, consumers have already stopped spending which leads to an increase in private sector savings, due to which a rise in taxes will not affect the overall market spending. The government can use this opportunity to borrow from the private sector, and it can act as an expansionary fiscal policy to boost economic growth.

clueweb22-en0007-34-08862.point_content: Tax cuts are bad for the long-term fiscal and economic outlook and may worsen recession by reducing capital and not guaranteeing reinvestment into the economy.
spans: Tax cuts, on the other hand, are bad not only for the long-term fiscal outlook, but also the long term economic outlook, as stated by the Congressional Budget Office. Tax cuts would result in smaller domestically owned stock of capital, and there would be no guarantee of these savings being injected into the economy, leading to a further state of recession.

clueweb22-en0007-34-08862.point_content: Tax cuts benefit the rich at the expense of the poor, leading to cuts in services beneficial to the poor.
spans: Further, tax cuts benefit the rich at the expense of the poor, as the services that will most likely get cut are beneficial to the poor; as seen with the repeal of the Affordable Care Act’s individual mandate in America in 2018 after the implementation of tax cuts by the Republican government.

clueweb22-en0007-34-08862.point_content: Increased government spending causes a multiplier effect, generating bigger increases in national income and benefiting various sectors.
spans: Increased government spending causes a “multiplier effect”, which occurs when the initial injection into the economy ripples and causes a bigger final increase in National Income.

clueweb22-en0007-34-08862.point_content: Historical examples show large government spending helped economies recover from recessions and build welfare states.
spans: The largest ever increase in government spending as a percentage of GDP occurred during post war periods, when economies were plagued, and governments had to find a way out. In the UK, close to 70% of the GDP was spent to create the welfare state – NHS, which included welfare benefits and council housing.

clueweb22-en0007-34-08862.point_content: Keynes explained government spending increases aggregate demand and maintains full employment, leading to economic growth.
spans: Through his book “The General Theory of Employment, Interest and Money”, Keynes explained that the government spending is a key component to increasing aggregate demand and maintaining full employment- translating to an increase in demand due to spending hikes.

clueweb22-en0007-34-08862.point_content: IMF and UN reports emphasize increased government spending as essential to recover from the COVID-19 recession and create jobs.
spans: According to a report published by the IMF, increasing spending by just 1% of GDP could create 33 million jobs.
According to a report published by the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, “Bold public spending is the only way to recover better from COVID-19”.

clueweb22-en0007-34-08862.point_content: Tax cuts boost the economy by increasing disposable income and consumer spending, leading to aggregate demand growth.
spans: Most economists agree that tax cuts boost the economy by putting more money into circulation.  Every worker, whether blue collar or white collar, sees an increase in his discretionary/disposable income. This extra money to spend ensures a rise in consumer spending at the macro-level.

clueweb22-en0007-34-08862.point_content: Tax cuts can have a long-run multiplier effect, stimulating enough growth to generate higher tax revenue eventually.
spans: Economist Arthur Laffer explained that tax cuts have a multiplier effect on the economy. Many tax cuts, during the Recession, had a fiscal multiplier greater than one, i.e. they stimulated enough growth in the long run to eventually generate higher tax revenue when there was more overall money to be taxed.

clueweb22-en0007-34-08862.point_content: Income tax cuts can increase productivity and economic growth, sometimes resulting in higher tax revenues despite lower rates.
spans: Income tax cuts can also increase productivity, which offset this fall in revenue. Tax cuts can thus often offer the best of both worlds: lower tax rates, but yet result in higher tax revenues and increased economic growth.

clueweb22-en0007-34-08862.point_content: Lower tax rates reduce tax evasion and avoidance, which helps in economic recovery during recessions.
spans: Lower tax rates always lead to a massive downfall in tax evasion and tax avoidance.

clueweb22-en0007-34-08862.point_content: Lower tax rates increase consumer and business confidence, encouraging investment and economic growth.
spans: Lower tax rates will increase confidence and general motivation, thus increasing investment, because the population at large feels less government intervention.

clueweb22-en0007-34-08862.point_content: In practice, recessions are fought with a combination of both tax cuts and spending hikes as expansionary fiscal policy.
spans: In a practical, real-world situation, recessions are never fought with one or the other; it is a combination of both tax cuts and spending hikes that is employed as an expansionary fiscal policy to overcome the recession.

clueweb22-en0003-20-17636.point_content: Spending cuts are superior to tax hikes when it comes to reducing the deficit.
spans: Some point to the deficit as a reason to raise taxes. But new research shows that spending cuts are superior to tax hikes when it comes to reducing the deficit.

clueweb22-en0003-20-17636.point_content: Raising taxes is not an effective way to address growing federal expenditures; cutting government spending has positive economic effects.
spans: The report demonstrates that raising taxes is not an effective way to address growing federal expenditures. Instead, it highlights the positive economic effects of actually cutting government spending.

clueweb22-en0003-20-17636.point_content: Countries that implemented spending cuts achieved deficit reduction and higher GDP, unlike those that increased taxes and faced deeper recessions.
spans: For instance, back in the 1980s, countries like Austria, Ireland, Belgium, and Denmark all accomplished deficit reduction and higher gross domestic product after implementing spending cuts.

Even after the global economic crisis of 2008, the countries that tried to boost federal revenue by increasing taxes were caught in much deeper recessions than countries who instead cut their expenditures.

clueweb22-en0003-20-17636.point_content: Tax increases undermine economic growth and do not control structural government spending increases like entitlement spending.
spans: Tax increases undermine economic growth.
In the long run, structural government spending increases, such as entitlement spending, can’t be controlled by hiking up taxes.

clueweb22-en0003-20-17636.point_content: Spending cuts enhance business confidence, while tax increases reduce incentives for investment and risk-proj-t-3jM9g14yGtzozJKYlWdtPW3nCuv8MoCKAkJPlQS7cBygKF6ur3tLm-pGfCEHxg5Jkk7lohYET3BlbkFJYfa6MImXvTLilGultWkvXMY8Cdcr6lofi2WkCxxuTZr37mtK8de78smZCWM3yLF6PiNIeNWEoA.
spans: Unlike tax increases, spending cuts directly enhance the confidence business owners and investors have in the economy.

The studies highlighted in the report strongly emphasize that when the government raises taxes, businesses are less likely to take financial risks, whether that be through investments or job creation.

clueweb22-en0003-20-17636.point_content: High business taxes cause businesses to relocate to countries with lower tax rates, boosting foreign economies.
spans: Moreover, countries with high business taxes face competition from other countries.
Countries with lower tax rates will appeal to businesses looking to expand or relocate.

clueweb22-en0003-20-17636.point_content: Short-term studies may show tax increases reduce deficits more than spending cuts, but long-term studies show spending cuts lead to higher deficit reductions over time.
spans: Studies that generate their data based on only one year show that an increase in taxes can achieve higher rates of deficit reduction with greater revenue than with spending cuts.
long-term studies show that cutting spending will lead to much higher rates of deficit reductions over time.

clueweb22-en0003-05-05752.point_content: Tax cuts are more efficient because firms following their self-interest will seek investments that provide profit.
spans: Tax cuts are more efficient because firms following their self-interest will seek investments that provide profit.

clueweb22-en0003-05-05752.point_content: Government spending is inefficient because the government has no incentive or barometer for efficient allocation of resources and cannot fail, leading to inefficiency.
spans: The government has no incentive or barometer for efficient allocation of resources. Rather than searching out arenas for profit growth, the government seeks to do damage control. Since the government does not seek profit, it has no way of telling how efficient it is in allocating resources. Unlike firms, the government cannot be allowed to fail, meaning there is no penalty for inefficiency and no competitive alternatives.

clueweb22-en0003-05-05752.point_content: Government spending often funds failing firms or projects, which does not help economic recovery effectively.
spans: Most importantly, the government is funding existing firms or projects, which are being funded because they have already failed or are on the brink of failure.

clueweb22-en0003-05-05752.point_content: Government spending increases GDP by only 1.4 dollars per dollar spent, while tax cuts can increase GDP by about 3 to 1.
spans: We often see government expenditure touted as the fastest way to improve GDP growth. With “each dollar of government spending” the GDP “increases…by only 1.4 dollars”.
The increase for endogenous tax cuts (i.e. tax cuts attempting to help a faltering economy) are estimated to show about 3 to 1 growth in GDP.

clueweb22-en0003-05-05752.point_content: Government spending must be paid by tax hikes, which can lower real GDP and investment, potentially worsening recession.
spans: Government spending and taxes are not separate issues. Governments can only pay off expenditures with tax hikes. The Romer study suggests that “an exogenous tax increase of one percent of GDP lowers real GDP by roughly three percent”, a phenomenon likely caused by the fact that “investment falls sharply in response to exogenous tax increases”.

clueweb22-en0003-05-05752.point_content: Example of JP Morgan Chase bailout shows government spending may not lead to economic improvement or job creation.
spans: A recent example would be JP Morgan Chase Bank’s 25 billion dollar bailout: a bailout they used to finance their own private acquisitions, not to make loans. They issued a statement that read “loan volume will continue to go down as we continue to tighten credit”. JP Morgan took 25 billion but did not provide much-needed loans to small businesses, employers, and individuals which would have helped, among other things, to create jobs and improve the housing market.

clueweb22-en0003-05-05752.point_content: Tax cuts create incentives for job creation and economic growth, as shown by historical examples like Reagan's tax cuts and Ireland's corporate tax policy.
spans: Taking a lower amount of taxes on a percentage basis is a short-term mechanism to stimulate economic growth that translates into higher taxes in the long term when there is more money overall to be taxed. President Reagan cut taxes during the 1980s in the United States, and all projections were assumed for revenue shortfalls, or if nothing else, no increases in overall taxation revenues. However, the taxation revenue on individual incomes increased from 1980 to 1989, nearly doubling, from $244 billion $446 billion.
In fact, when recession hit the United States in 1919, a series of tax cuts over the next nine years kept the economy stable, and the recession itself was over within two years.

An increase in jobs is a fundamental part of getting out of a recession. Consumer spending needs to be increased in order to see tangible growth in the economy and consumer spending can not be increased as long as consumers remain unemployed. The most efficient way to create jobs is to decrease corporate taxes that create incentives to create new jobs.
For example, the state of Michigan enacted policy that substantially decreased corporate taxes on companies that created new jobs in high-growth sectors such as green and bio technology.
The purpose of business is to profit and through corporate tax cuts, business will have the ability to profit easier while creating jobs.
This is proven in the example of Ireland, which adopted a 12.5% corporate tax in 1988 while having the second-lowest per capita income in Europe and now has the second-highest income in Europe.

clueweb22-en0003-05-05752.point_content: Government spending creates short-term jobs that do not provide long-term economic growth or stability.
spans: Government spending can also create jobs but the question is are these jobs suitable for getting out of a recession? The answer is a resounding no.
Let’s examine one of the largest attempts by government to create jobs, Roosevelt’s Public Works Administration which allocated $3.3 billion dollars for public jobs to stimulate employment.
The jobs created by it usually lasted only months allowing only short term employment and the unemployment rate remained above 9%.
Many of the jobs consisted of building public structures and murals such as a mountain theater that were not done to grow the economy further but to grow political capital.
After the expenditures stopped, so did the jobs.
Only private industry can provide the long term stability and job creation through new and improved investments which are vital economic necessities to get out of a recession.
